item.title: Starfield: Shattered Space Preview – Getting back to what Bethesda does best
item.content:encoded:
https://www.thesixthaxis.com/2024/08/27/starfield-shattered-space-preview-getting-back-to-what-bethesda-does-best/

For all the years of build up and anticipation, Starfield’s launch last September didn’t exactly set the world alight. It took a bold step into sci-fi with its interstellar adventure, but felt like it didn’t quite explore its galaxy of possibilities as fully as it could have done. Launching on 30th September, Starfield: Shattered Space, the first big expansion for the game, looks set to take one of the dangling threads of potential and head down a dark and twisted rabbit hole.

Throughout the version of Starfield that shipped, you can see the vestigial remnants of some of the many gameplay experiments and ideas that Bethesda explored through the game’s eight years of development. Some remain as gameplay elements with little meaningful purpose, like building bases to refine fuel for space travel that was eventually made practically limitless, while others were left as dangling threads waiting to be revisited, like House Va’ruun.

This bunch of fanatical space serpent worshippers were easily one of the most enigmatic aspects of the main game. Ostensibly one of the biggest factions in the Settled Systems, alongside the United Colonies and FreeStar Collective, they were almost nowhere to be seen, outside of historical context and having Andreja as one of your possible companions. The presence of Va’ruun’kai, their homeworld, was kept a closely guarded secret as they retreated into isolation.

Also weird as heck experiments. Shattered Space reveals the location of Va’ruun’kai and the capital city of Dazra in the wake of a reality tearing experiment by their leading scientists, with extra-dimensional beings flooding through.

Va’ruun’kai promises to be a dark and unsettling locale to explore, the planet shrouded in deep, dark reds and purples from its sky that lend it a deeply ominous tone, while Dazra itself has been engulfed in a spatial anomaly and surrounded by a suspended explosion. Still, Dazra is basically the one safe place left on the planet, with the Va’ruun evacuating other settlements and places from across the planet to reach its relative safety.

House Va’ruun is threatened on all sides, the most eye-catching being the enemies that can burst out from another reality, whether they’re new long-limbed bugs or humanoids that are reminiscent of Spider-Man villain Mister Negative or Destiny’s Taken. There’s the potential to explore some real cosmic horrors through this rend in time and space that they’ve created, especially if Bethesda choose to reveal more about the Great Serpent itself.

While the trailers look to lean in on the horror aspect, I’m not sure the expansion will really be all that terrifying. Battling these enemies, Bethesda is pushing the combat in a subtly different direction that might ramp up the pressure and challenge you in different ways. There could be more zero-G battles, you’ll have more hostiles to deal with when exploring the wider surface of Va’ruun’kai and you’ll probably want the Rev-8 to help outrun things, but also there’s a shifting emphasis on enemies that will bullrush you and try to get within melee range. If you went through the main game hunkering down behind cover constantly, that might no longer be an option in Shattered Space as you’re pushed to stay mobile and make use of the jet pack.

However, just as impactful to this expansion will be the threats to House Va’ruun from within. There’s a power vacuum at the top of this space empire and all of the sub-factions and lesser figures are vying to step up to the big time. You’ll no doubt have a hand in deciding you gets to lead House Va’ruun into the future, and there will no doubt be the full gamut of reasonable leaders and full-on galaxy destroying nutters.

With the galaxy of systems and planets already generated, Bethesda’s expansions to Starfield can take on a much more hand-crafted approach. Shattered Space is the first fruits of this labour, building within this established framework to expand the universe narrative and make this a game worth revisiting.

item.title: Suikoden I & II HD Remaster: Gate Rune And Dunan Unification Wars Release Date Confirmed; New Trailer Released
item.content:encoded:
https://wccftech.com/suidkoen-i-ii-remaster-release-date/

After months of silence, Suikoden I & II HD Remaster: Gate Rune And Dunan Unification Wars has finally resurfaced, and with a final release date to boot.

In today's Nintendo Partner Direct, it has been confirmed that the collection featuring the first two entries in the beloved JRPG series by Konami will be released on March 6th on Nintendo Switch. Konami has yet to confirm the release date for PC and PlayStation consoles, but it will likely be the same as the Nintendo Switch release. A new trailer showcasing some of the remasters' features was also shared online, and you can find it below.

As showcased in the trailer above, Suikoden I & II HD Remaster: Gate Rune And Dunan Unification Wars will come with plenty of improvements over the original releases, such as enhanced visuals featuring pixel sprites and environments with new screen effects and shadow animations, redone character portraits and more. The two games will both receive some gameplay improvements and new quality-of-life features such as a dialogue log, auto-battle, the ability to speed up battles, and more. For the rest, it will be the same classic JRPGs that fans have come to love. The second game, in particular, is considered by many the best entry in the series and one of the best JRPGs ever released, thanks to its excellent story and gameplay.

Suikoden I & II HD Remaster: Gate Rune And Dunan Unification Wars launches on March 6th on Nintendo Switch. The game should be released on PC, PlayStation, and Xbox consoles on the same day.

item.title: Nintendo Direct August 2024 Shows - All the Announcements and Reveals
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/nintendo-direct-august-2024-recap

Today, Nintendo held two Nintendo Direct presentations back-to-back: a Partner Showcase and an Indie World event. Here are all of the announcements and reveals from both events!

First, let's start with the Indie World show. Here's everything you need to know from that show!

Balatro's big crossover adventure

Hugely successful indie poker roguelike Balatro is getting a whole bunch of crossovers. The Witcher, Vampire Survivors, Dave the Diver, and Among Us all made an appearance.

Neva is very much a new game from the Gris folks

The creators of Gris are working on a new game, Neva, which sees you teaming up with a young wolf cub to navigate a very artsy-looking world full of shadows. It's coming to Switch on October 15th.

Moth Kubit plonks you into an insect bureaucracy

In this surreal RPG, you play as Moth, a worker in a labyrinthine insect bureaucracy who must uncover a sinister conspiracy while also meeting with some very unique characters. This one's heading to Switch next spring.

Coffee Talk Tokyo is a spinoff set in - you guessed it - Tokyo

Cozy coffee shop sim Coffee Talk is getting a spinoff set in Tokyo, and it'll bring the same sort of cute vibes and chilled-out gameplay you've come to expect. You can play it on Switch next year.

DLC sizzle reel time!

Next, we get to see some upcoming DLC for existing games. We get to see Sea of Stars' Throes of the Watchmaker DLC (coming spring 2025) and PowerWash Simulator's Shrek DLC (arriving this fall).

Morsels is a "grungy" card-based shootin' roguelike

The first ever trailer for Annapurna and developer Furcula's grungy roguelike Morsels is up next, and if you like crunchy pixels, you'll love this. Strong Nuclear Throne energy to this one. It's coming to Switch in February.

Date Everything! lets you, well, date everything

It's now time for a look at Team17's inanimate object dating sim Date Everything!. You might not be able to date literally everything, but the game comes pretty darn close. It hits Switch on October 24th.

Peglin's "fun and physics-y" goblin adventure comes to Switch

Imagine a cross between Peggle and goblins. Got that in your head? That's pretty much what Peglin looks like. It's a casual puzzle game roguelike with turn-based battling, and it's heading to Switch as a timed exclusive later today.

Wacky life sim RPG Wobbly Life looks fun

If you like Human: Fall Flat and Fantasy Life and wish they could merge together...well, that's weird, but Wobbly Life is for you, and you can play it on Switch in December.

Pico Park 2 features jolly co-operation

Have you played Pico Park? Want more of it? Well, naturally, Pico Park 2 is for you. It features more co-op challenges and lots of different mechanics, so collect your friends and put your friendships to the test later today.

Indie sizzle reel time!

It's time for another sizzle reel. Here's what we saw!

  • Shovel Knight: Shovel of Hope DX (2025)
  • Europa (October 11th, demo today) 
  • Cuisineer (January 28th)
  • On Your Tail (November 21st)
  • Metal Slug Tactics (fall 2024)
  • The Plucky Squire (September 17th)

One more thing...it's Pizza Tower time

As the final announcement in today's Indie World show, Wario Land-inspired platformer Pizza Tower is heading to Switch. It joins the console's software lineup later today!

Nintendo Direct Indie World Presentation August 2024 - all the announcements

Next up, it's time for a recap of everything we saw in the Nintendo Direct Partner Showcase. Here we go!

Tetris' 40th anniversary gets its own compilation

To celebrate 40 years of Tetris, a new Tetris compilation is being released, packing in a whole bunch of old-school Tetris games (plus a brand new one) for all the tetrominoes you could hope for. It hits Switch later this year, and the NES version is coming to Switch Online in winter.

Star Overdrive is a "high-speed sci-fi adventure"

Dear Villagers showed off a new open-world-looking sci-fi adventure called Star Overdrive, which features truly radical-looking board traversal, melee combat, and Zelda-style puzzles. You can play it as a timed exclusive on Switch next year.

Goat Simulator 3 is coming to Switch

Yep. Goat Simulator 3, the hi-lariously wacky sandbox adventure from Coffee Stain, is coming to Nintendo Switch in all its goatly glory. The Switch gets its goat on later today, and a physical version's coming in November.

It's sizzle reel time!

Next, we got a look at some of the games coming to Switch in the next few months. Here they are!

  • The Legend of Heroes: Trails in the Sky the 1st - 2025
  • Star Wars: Hunters - September 26th
  • S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Legends of the Zone Trilogy - November
  • Worms Armageddon: Anniversary Edition - September 26th
  • Disney Dreamlight Valley's new event - September 4th

SpongeBob SquarePants: The Patrick Star Game isn't SpongeBob, it's Patrick

A new SpongeBob sandbox adventure in which you play as Patrick was revealed during today's show. With plenty of varied tasks to complete, SpongeBob characters to meet, and more, this one looks fun. It's heading to Switch on October 4th.

Fitness Boxing 3: Your Personal Trainer wants to help you get fit

A new Fitness Boxing game is heading to Switch, and it's got new workout features and brand new exercise-friendly songs to help you get fitter. This one boxes its way to Switch on December 5th.

Capcom Fighting Collection 2 wants to take you for another ride

Eight retro Capcom fighting games are coming to Switch as part of this brand new collection. Between Capcom crossover games, Street Fighter classics, and even the Dreamcast's Power Stone, there's plenty here for fighting aficionados. It hits Switch next year.

Marvel vs. Capcom Fighting Collection: Arcade Classics is also heading to the Switch in September.

Atelier Yumia: The Alchemist of Memories & the Envisioned Land arrives next year

Another improbably-titled Atelier adventure is coming to Switch sometime early next year, and it looks exactly like what you'd expect from the series; lots of highfalutin storytelling, a wondrous land to explore, and more.

Suikoden I & II HD Remaster Gate Rune and Dunan Unification Wars arrives in March

That name's a real mouthful, isn't it? Remasters of the first two Suikoden games were announced almost two years ago, and today, we learned they're heading to Switch on March 6th.

Dragon Quest III HD-2D Remake sure does look pretty

It's a quick look at Dragon Quest III HD-2D Remake next, and it sure does look nice with Square Enix's signature HD-2D style. As we know, this one's coming on November 14th.

Castlevania Dominus Collection resurrects three classics

Now this is what I'm talking about. The three Castlevania DS adventures - that's Dawn of Sorrow, Portrait of Ruin, and Order of Ecclesia - are getting Switch re-releases later today, along with arcade classic Haunted Castle.

Sid Meier's Civilization VII hits Switch in February

As was announced during last week's Gamescom show, Civilization VII is coming in February, and it's coming to Switch as well. We got to see some of the game in action during today's show.

Tales of Graces f Remastered celebrates the series' 30th anniversary in January

If you're a big fan of the Tales JRPG series, you'll appreciate this one. Tales of Graces f is getting a remaster, complete with new destination icons, the ability to toggle battles, and more. It comes to Switch on January 17th.

MySims Cozy Bundle is a cute take on The Sims

The Sims meets Animal Crossing probably isn't the perfect pitch for MySims Cozy Bundle, but it's not a million miles off either. You'll be able to play two remastered MySims games on Switch on November 19th.

Five Nights at Freddy's: Help Wanted 2 jumpscares its way to Switch this holiday

As if the Switch couldn't get spooky enough, Nintendo announced that Five Nights at Freddy's: Help Wanted 2 is making its way to Switch this holiday season. Not only that, but Five Nights at Freddy's: Security Breach is getting some free DLC, too.

Holiday sizzle reel time!

Next, it's time for a look at some of the games coming to Switch this holiday season, and here they are!

  • Disney Epic Mickey: Rebrushed - September 24th
  • Tales of the Shire: A The Lord of the Rings Game - Holiday 2024
  • Just Dance 2025 Edition - October 15th
  • Funko Fusion - Holiday 2024
  • EA Sports FC 25 - September 27th
  • Lego Horizon Adventures - Holiday 2024

Rune Factory: Guardians of Azuma is a new "fresh take" on the series

Promising a "bigger adventure than ever before", Rune Factory: Guardians of Azuma sees you dancing and using sacred objects to help grow crops, revitalize the land, and restore Azuma to its former glory.

There's also a community of NPCs to meet, lots of monsters to fight, and a beautiful anime-inspired world to explore. Guardians of Azuma comes to Switch in spring 2025.

Yakuza Kiwami brings Kiryu and Majima to Switch

Lastly, it's time for Kazuma Kiryu and Goro Majima to make their way to the Switch, as Yakuza Kiwami arrives on Nintendo's console on October 24th. Interestingly enough, it hasn't been renamed to Like a Dragon Kiwami in keeping with the series' name change.

Whew! That's everything. Thanks for joining us for this recap! Stay tuned for more on all things Nintendo-related.

item.title: Balatro Friends of Jimbo Deals a Hand of Collaborations With Witcher, Among Us, and More
item.content:encoded:
https://www.ign.com/articles/balatro-friends-of-jimbo-deals-a-hand-of-collaborations-with-witcher-among-us-and-more

Vampire Survivors and Dave the Diver join the deck.

Today, Nintendo's Indie World Showcase opened with a treat for Balatro fans. The game is getting collaborations with four exciting properties later today in the new Friends of Jimbo update: The Witcher, Vampire Survivors, Dave the Diver, and Among Us.

The collaborations appear to contain themed decks with cards styled after characters from each game, potentially with exciting new effects. The Dave the Diver deck, for instance, changes the number cards to fruit, and the Among Us deck seems to include death animations for playing certain hands. Given the nature of Balatro, it's possible that some of the new additions are cards with interesting twists.

The trailer was short, so it's not quite clear the extent to which each theme shuffles the deck, but given that it's a free update, no strings attached, it's an exciting little bonus for folks already excited about the most addictive card game of the year.

Balatro Friends of Jimbo Nintendo Direct August 2024 Screenshots

Balatro came out on all major platforms back in February, and was immediately lauded as a critical and commercial hit. In our 9/10 review, we called this twist on poker "the sort of fun that threatens to derail whole weekend plans." A free "major gameplay update" is expected for Balatro in 2025 according to the official X/Twitter, which will "bring new ideas and strategies to the game."

Rebekah Valentine is a senior reporter for IGN. Got a story tip? Send it to rvalentine@ign.com.

Due out in 2025.

Capcom has announced classic fighting games collection Capcom Fighting Collection 2 for PlayStation 4, Switch, and PC (Steam). It will launch in 2025.

Here is an overview of the collection, via Capcom:

About

Combining hard-hitting classics like Capcom vs. SNK 2: Mark of the Millennium 2001 with fan favorite brawlers like Power Stone 2 in one knockout package, Capcom Fighting Collection 2 comes chock-full of new features including online play and quality-of-life updates across all eight games!

Capcom Fighting Collection 2 is a lights-out collection of fighting games and fun-filled classics hitting modern platforms for the first time, including:

  • Capcom vs. SNK: Millennium Fight 2000 Pro
  • Capcom vs. SNK 2: Mark of the Millennium 2001
  • Capcom Fighting Evolution
  • Street Fighter Alpha 3 UPPER
  • Project Justice
  • Power Stone
  • Power Stone 2
  • Plasma Sword: Nightmare of Bilstein
  • ❮
  • ❯

Key Features

  • Face Off with Friends Online – Online play is available across all eight titles, featuring rollback netcode for a strong and stable online experience!
  • Hit the Training Bag – Training Mode is now available across all titles with tons of customizable options!
  • Expanded Language Support! – 14 languages will be supported including English, Latin American Spanish, Brazilian Portuguese, Japanese, French, Italian, German, Castilian Spanish, Russian, Polish, Korean, Simplified Chinese, Traditional Chinese, and Arabic!
  • A Museum’s Worth of Content – Explore art and music galleries with official art, concept art, design documents, and more never-before-seen content.
  • Customize Your Experience – Fine-tune specific features of your gameplay experience via EX Settings specialized to each game, various Display Filters, button customization, and more.
  • Need a Snack Break? – Mid-game saves have now been added!
  • Additional Updates – Various gameplay balance adjustments and quality of life improvements across all eight games.

Physical edition to follow on November 22.

Fighting games collection Marvel vs. Capcom Fighting Collection: Arcade Classics will launch digitally for PlayStation 4, Switch, and PC via Steam on September 12, Capcom announced. A physical edition will follow for PlayStation 4 and Switch on November 22, with all physical pre-orders including an exclusive, 32-page comic featuring characters and Super Heroes from across the various titles in the collection.

Here is an overview of the collection, via Capcom:

About

Join fans from around the world in celebrating the legacy of some of the most beloved fighting games with the release of Marvel vs. Capcom Fighting Collection: Arcade Classics. This jam-packed collection includes seven timeless games in an all-in-one package, including:

  • X-Men: Children of the Atom
  • Marvel Super Heroes
  • Marvel vs. Capcom: Clash of Super Heroes
  • Marvel vs. Capcom 2: New Age of Heroes
  • Marvel Super Heroes vs. Street Fighter
  • X-Men vs. Street Fighter
  • The Punisher

Key Features

  • Battle It Out Online – All of the fighting games in the collection will have online ranked, casual, and lobby matches unlocked for players to showcase their abilities with friends, family, and other players from around the world!
  • Robust Rollback Netcode – Online play for the collection is supported with rollback netcode for a strong and stable online experience!
  • Be the Best! – Global high score leaderboards come to every game in the collection so players can track their journey to the top of the list!
  • Practice Makes Perfect – Training Mode comes to all fighting games in the collection so players can learn, practice, and master their moves!
  • A Rare Gem – The classic beat ‘em up arcade game The Punisher comes to PC and modern consoles for the first time ever in the United States!
  • Watch This! – Spectator Mode is available so you can enjoy watching your friends and co-combatants battle it out!
  • Additional Features – Check out the collection’s enhanced features like a music jukebox, in-game Museum, new display filters, and more!

For Capcom fans, fighting game enthusiasts, comic book and Super Hero aficionados, and everyone in between, Marvel vs. Capcom Fighting Collection: Arcade Classics offers a timeless celebration of a legacy fighting game series, delivering a diverse roster of iconic characters, enhanced features and competitive gameplay. Relive the nostalgia or discover enduring classics for the first time, uniting fans of all generations in celebration of Capcom’s legendary fighting game series.

item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/lego-horizon-adventures-release-date-announced/1100-6526132/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Lego Horizon Adventures, described as a "playful and light-hearted" re-telling of Sony's Horizon: Zero Dawn franchise, will launch on November 14, according to a leak. The game showed up during the Nintendo Direct on August 27, but Nintendo only reiterated the "Holiday 2024" date and did not provide a specific date.

Gematsu reported that the PlayStation website's homepage briefly listed a November 14 release date for Lego Horizon Adventures, though it's since been updated to remove it. There is said to be a PlayStation State of Play event in September, and some believe Sony could announce the release date for Lego Horizon Adventures then.

Lego Horizon Adventures is co-developed by Guerrilla Games and Studio Gobo, and will launch on Switch, PS4, PS5, and PC. There is no word yet on an Xbox release for the game.

Lego Horizon Adventures re-tells the general story of Horizon, which follows the hero Aloy and her life in a harsh and unforgiving world full of dinosaur-like machine creatures. The game supports solo play or co-op locally and online.

item.title: PS5 Will Become About $90 More Expensive In This Major Market
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/ps5-will-become-about-90-more-expensive-in-this-major-market/1100-6526135/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Usually, video game consoles get cheaper as the years pass by. But that's not the case for the PS5 in Japan. In fact, Sony is about to raise the price for both PS5 models there by 13,000 yen on September 2, which is roughly about $90 in the US.

On X, The Verge senior reporter Tom Warren highlighted the price hike for the PS5 in Japan. He also pointed out that this will be the third time Sony has raised the price for the system in Japan since the PS5 launched in late 2020.

For instance, almost exactly two years ago, Sony increased the price for PS5 in a lot of regions outside the US, including Japan. Sony cited global inflation and adverse currency trends as the reasons behind the price hikes at the time.

Earlier this month, Sony revealed that PS5 hardware sales were down about 27% year over year for the company's first quarter of fiscal year 2024--April 1 to June 30. Lifetime sales of PS5 have surpassed 60 million systems.

Looking ahead, a new report says a PS5 Pro could be coming this year and cost $600. The expected release date for the new system would be October or November, and the price could go as high as $700.

item.title: Yakuza Kiwami is coming to Nintendo Switch in October
item.content:encoded:
https://www.thesixthaxis.com/2024/08/27/yakuza-kiwami-is-coming-to-nintendo-switch-in-october/

Yakuza Kiwami, the 2016/17 remake of the PS2 classic, is coming to Nintendo Switch on 24th October 2024.

The first game in the long-running Japanese crime thriller series (though not the earliest story told in the series, which would be the prequel Yakuza 0), Yakuza Kiwami sees the iconic protagonist Kazuma Kiryu come out of prison 10 years after taking the fall for a murder, and then being dropped right back into the battle between yakuza clans.

There’s an epic story to be told here, but this is also a dense open world that’s full of things to see and do. Kamurocho, a fictional district of Tokyo based on the real-life Kabukichō district is a haven for side missions, mini-games and random enemy encounters.

Bringing the series to the Nintendo Switch for the first time is a pretty great move by RGG Studio and Sega, though we’ll have to wait and see how the game handles the jump to the low powered system. The game did originally launch for PS3 and PS4 in Japan in 2016, though only the PS4 version was localised for other regions. There’s other great places to play this, including Xbox consoles, PC and even PC handhelds… but there’s also just something to the Switch and its relatively light handheld form that will surely appeal.

item.title: Coffee Talk Tokyo sips Japanese coffee in 2025
item.content:encoded:
https://www.thesixthaxis.com/2024/08/27/coffee-talk-tokyo-sips-japanese-coffee-in-2025/

The beloved Coffee Talk visual novel series will carry on with Coffee Talk Tokyo, coming to Nintendo Switch in 2025.

The Coffee Talk team at Toge Production – represented by AJ and Dio in the announcement – is carrying on the legacy of co-creator and writer Mohammad Fahmi Hasni, who sadly passed away in early 2022. They’ve reunited with co-writer of Episode 2, Anna Winterstein of Chorus, and Kimitaka Ogawa, writer and English-to-Japanese translator who localised the originals.

Combined, they are producing Coffee Talk Tokyo, bringing a more Japanese flavour to the game with things like a matcha latte, while listening to the stories of love, loss, joy and sadness that your patrons share.

item.title: Fairy Tail 2 Launches This December on PC and Consoles; New Trailer Released

Fairy Tail 2 will be released this December on PC and consoles, Koei Tecmo confirmed today.

The second entry in the series developed by GUST, which will bring the original story to its conclusion with the Alvarez arc, will launch on PC on December 11th and on PlayStation 5, PlayStation 4, and Nintendo Switch on December 13th. To mark the announcement, a new trailer was released, providing a first look at the magic battles Natsu and the team must unleash in order to defeat their greatest enemy, Zeref, the Emperor Spriggan of the Alvarez Empire. You can check out the trailer below.

In addition to the game's standard edition, the Fairy Tail 2 GUILD BOX will be available at launch exclusively through the NIS America store. This special edition includes the base game, the visual artbook “Sorcerer Magazine Special Issue: Game Release Edition Vol.2” inspired by the “Sorcerer Magazine” as seen in the original work, a Special Shikishi with Holographic Finish (three types in total), and more.

Fairy Tail 2 launches on PC on December 11th and on PlayStation 5, PlayStation 4, and Nintendo Switch on December 13th. Expect to see my full hands-on preview of the game from this year's Gamescom in the coming days.

item.content:encoded:
https://www.theverge.com/2024/8/27/24229056/mysims-nintendo-switch-remastered-launch

MySims is back, and it’s coming to the Nintendo Switch. A new bundle featuring revamped versions of EA’s MySims and MySims Kingdom will revive the classic simulation titles with Switch-optimized controls and updated textures.

If you’ve never played MySims, it’s sort of like a cross between The Sims and Animal Crossing. In the mainline game, you’re tasked with rebuilding a run-down town by procuring blueprints, constructing houses, and making furniture to attract new residents. Each character has their own unique characteristics, like the bug-loving Gertrude Spackle and Yuki, who often threatens to bite your face for some reason.

MySims launched on the Wii and Nintendo DS in 2007 before arriving on PC and Blackberry. MySims Kingdom, which switches up the original gameplay by putting you inside a royal setting, launched on the Wii and Nintendo DS a year later. There have been several other entries in the series as well, including MySims Agents, MySims Party, MySims Racing, and MySims SkyHeroes.

It feels like it’s been ages since I got my hands on a MySims game, and I’m excited to jump back in. I just kind of wish EA created a new entry with refreshed stories and characters specifically for the Switch, instead of simply remastering the old games. But, hey, maybe that will happen down the line. There’s been a lot going on with The Sims franchise as of late — along with MySims, EA is also working on a new free-to-play Sims game, codenamed Project Rene.

MySims: Cozy Bundle launches on the Nintendo Switch on November 19th for $39.99, and preorders are available starting today.

item.title: Activision cancelled Crash Bandicoot 5 to make room for more online live service games, claims report
item.content:encoded:
https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/activision-cancelled-crash-bandicoot-5-to-make-room-for-more-online-live-service-games-claims-report

Binned-off sequel might have featured a Spyro team-up

I find it bizarre that people still really like Crash Bandicoot games in this, the year 2024, two decades after the decline of the platform mascot warz. I have ample nostalgia for the old marsupial myself, with his second Naughty Dog-developed outing being a particular obsession, but come now, we're all about deckbuilders, soulsliking and battle royale nowadays, right?

Still, I'll admit to a twinge of disappointment after reading that a Crash Bandicoot 5 was once in development at Crash 4: It's About Time developers Toys For Bob, and might have featured an interdimensional team-up with one of Crash's old rivals. No, not Mario.

The rumour in question has been mongered by video game historian Liam Robertson (via EG), who claims that Crash 5 would have been another single player 3D platformer and a direct sequel to Crash 4, which released in 2020. Robertson has also gotten hold of some alleged artworks and story concepts. One proposal envisaged a game set in a school for villainous kids, featuring returning villains such as Dr Cortex. Another would have seen Crash join forces with Mr Spyro of the Dragon family - another darling of the mascot era and patient zero for Toys For Bob's currently on-hiatus Skylanders toys-to-life series.

But then along came the axemen of Activision, with their brutal talk of Crash 4 'not meeting sales expectations' and online live service games being 'all of the rage'. Crash 5 was apparently cancelled in the very early days of development to make room for another live service-me-do. Team members were moved to other projects such as Crash Team Rumble, released last year, which didn't exactly set the world alight.

Toys For Bob washed their hands of Activision and went independent earlier this year, following a round of layoffs. Back in March, studio heads Paul Yan and Avery Lodato declared that they were "in the early days of developing our next new game and a ways away from making any announcements". I wonder if any of those abandoned ideas for Crash 5 have made their way into the studio's current projects.

item.title: Tetris Forever is Coming to Nintendo Switch in 2024
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/tetris-forever-is-coming-to-nintendo-switch-in-2024/

In a new trailer released today, Nintendo announced Tetris Forever is coming to the Switch in 2024 with a new trailer as part of the latest Direct Partner showcase.

Tetris Forever celebrates the 40th anniversary of the original Tetris game, compiling a wide range of classic titles in the series.

Today’s new trailer description reveals that Tetris Forever is an “interactive documentary game.” Fans can play “more than 15 different classic Tetris games while exploring the history of the series through over an hour of all-new documentary footage.”

Unfortunately, today’s trailer did not confirm an exact release date for Tetris Forever. However, the new trailer did mention that the NES version of Tetris is coming to Nintendo Switch Online in Winter 2024. That will also coincide with a Tetris 99 Maximus Cup event.

So, it’s possible that Tetris Forever will try to launch around the same time as that release.

The original Tetris gained a lot of renewed interest following a live-action film based on its origins.

Earlier this year, a 13-year-old player also finally beat Tetris. Also, just last month, Minecraft got Tetris DLC, so fans will surely be pleased to revisit the classic titles with Tetris Forever sometime in 2024.

item.title: Sea of Stars free DLC ‘Throes of the Watchmaker’ announced
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gematsu.com/2024/08/sea-of-stars-free-dlc-throes-of-the-watchmaker-announced

Sabotage Studio has announced Sea of Stars downloadable content “Throes of the Watchmaker.” It will launch for free in spring 2025.

Get the details below.

About

This Sea of Stars downloadable content finds the Solstice Warriors Valere and Zale venturing into the miniature clockwork world of Horloge. In this magical land where denizens are threatened by a cursed carnival, our heroes will need to adapt to unfamiliar rules if their Sun and Moon powers are to manifest.

“Throes of the Watchmaker” is coming for free to all platforms in spring 2025!

Key Features

  • New Playable Classes for Valere and Zale – The world of Horloge plays by different rules, and for their magic to manifest, the Solstice Warriors will need to adapt. Zale will tap into his agility to become a Juggler, while Valere will harness her balance to dazzle as an Acrobat. Playing to the circus-themed curse, they will unlock a completely new set of attacks, damage types, skills and combos.
  • New Playable Character: Arty – Artificer joins the party! The friendly engineer robot will finally unlock the laser-shooting capabilities of his construct, and join Valere and Zale in the fight to save Horloge.
  • New Areas, Music, Enemies, Bosses, and Puzzles – Journey into a magical miniature clockwork world where a plethora of oddities and wonders await. The world of Horloge, where a cursed carnival threatens the innocent denizens, is filled with unique environments, NPCs, enemies and dungeons. And of course, Sabotage’s composer Eric W. Brown returns to bring a completely fresh set of tracks!
  • Local Cooperative With Up to Three Players – The upcoming local cooperative mode will also be available for Throes of the Watchmaker. It will allow up to three players to engage in traversal and combat with a new “Co-Op timed hits” mechanic! Disclaimer: this update is also coming to Sea of Stars’ main adventure Q4 2024.

Sea of Stars is available now for PlayStation 5, Xbox Series, PlayStation 4, Xbox One, Switch, and PC via Steam.

item.title: Studio Imugi is ditching 'oatmeal' narrative design with Bonaparte-A Mechanized Revolution
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamedeveloper.com/design/studio-imugi-is-ditching-oatmeal-narrative-design-with-bonaparte-a-mechanized-revolution

Bonaparte–A Mechanized Revolution is the upcoming steampunk-infused 4X strategy title from Studio Imugi, the Canadian studio established by former Kitfox Games and Sabotage developers back in 2021.

The indie outfit has been quietly chipping away on the project since the pandemic, securing vital funding in the form of grants from the Canadian government and Ubisoft, scaling up from three co-founders to eight employees, implementing a four-day work week, and mulling over how they can punch above their weight in a genre dominated by juggernauts like Paradox, Firaxis, and more.

Speaking to Game Developer at Gamescom 2024, creative director Jongwoo Kim explains Bonaparte will empower players by ensuring they don't "railroad" them into choices.

He feels strategy titles and tactical RPGs often ignore the wider context of decision making to force players down certain roads. Discussing the grand strategy genre, specifically, Kim notes those titles are so "zoomed out" –often spanning hundreds of years–they also struggle to humanise their characters and narratives, leaving players struggling to establish meaningful emotional connections.

To counter those perceived pitfalls, he says Bonaparte will  "really zoom in on a narrow point in history where a lot happens."

"We're looking at the revolutionary decade from 1789 to 1799 for the initial release, and there is so much in there in terms of big personalities and big ideas," he says, noting that the real-life Napoleon Bonaparte was initially quite "ambivalent politically" making them the perfect wildcard for players to inhabit in an outlandish alternate history.

"We emphasize that you are not Napoleon. You are Bonaparte in an alternate timeline. You are not bound by Napoleon's choices. You can choose to make your radical worker's republic if you really want to go for that. Or if you want to choose to be the king's lackey, you can also do that," says Kim.

"In terms of depicting history in games, often there's a belief that history is just the names, places, and dates. That's actually the boring stuff. What's interesting is why people do something. What were the dynamics behind these factions? Why couldn't they come to peace?"

Kim says Bonaparte will look to deliver "alternate history with authenticity," but notes that players shouldn't expect a full blown historical simulation. The title will take place during a niche period and focus on a select few historical figures, letting players become deeply immersed in a moment in time rather than pulling them across multiple generations.

How does that play to their advantage in a market with a litany of expansive historical strategy titles? Kim believes Imugi's approach can win players over by eschewing "oatmeal" narrative design conventions. "It's about having more meaningful outcomes from your choices," he continues.

"I think grand strategy games with a massive scale allow us to have a lot of choices that really change games and their outcomes, [but] there's a saying in game narrative circles about oatmeal experiences. There are these bumps, but there's so small and they're everywhere so you don't really notice that each bump is actually a meaningful choice. By really zooming in on this era and focusing on key figures I think we'll have a much more defined experience."

Kim hopes it's an approach that can turn Bonaparte into a "spicy appetiser." A delectable morsel that, while not quite as hearty as oatmeal, is altogether more potent.

item.title: PowerWash Simulator heading to Shrek's fairytale world this autumn
item.content:encoded:
https://www.eurogamer.net/powerwash-simulator-heading-to-shreks-fairytale-world-this-autumn

In latest bit of paid DLC .

PowerWash Simulator's collaborations are set to continue this autumn when players will have the opportunity to whip out their squirters and give Shrek's fairytale world a good hose down in a brand-new paid DLC.

PowerWash Simulator's Shrek Special Pack marks the fifth bit of paid DLC for video gaming's premiere wash-'em-up, following on from collaborations with Spongebob SquarePants, Back to the Future, Warhammer 40,000, and Alice's Adventures in Wonderland - and that's alongside free seasonal content and more.

Developer FuturLab's Shrek Special Pack promises five new "fairytale" maps inspired by the Dreamworks' currently four-strong animated movie series, with levels revealed so far including Shrek's Swamp and the Dragon's Lair.

As is customary, it'll also including a new outfit to don while blasting off the grime, this time resembling a set of knight's shining armour. And if PowerWash Simulator's Shrek DLC is anywhere near as good as its surprisingly excellent Alice DLC, we're in for a treat.

There's no release date yet for PowerWash Simulator's Shrek Special Pack, but expect it to cost around £6.50 when it shows up for all platforms this "autumn". And in the meantime, there's plenty of free stuff to de-filth, thanks to FuturLab's recent summer celebrations and Washer-Versary.

item.title: Gris developer's next game Neva secures October release date
item.content:encoded:
https://www.eurogamer.net/gris-developers-next-game-neva-secures-october-release-date

The sad and beautiful wolf adventure Neva has a release date.

Neva, which was initially announced back in May last year, will launch across PC, Nintendo Switch, PS5 and Xbox Series X/S on 15th October, the team announced during today's Nintendo Direct. On its release, it will retail at £16.99.

Described as an "emotionally-charged new adventure", Neva follows the story of a young woman named Alba and her lifelong bond with a wolf.

"Following a traumatic encounter with dark forces, Alba finds herself bound to a curious, mischievous wolf cub. Working together, the pair will help each other overcome increasingly dangerous situations," reads the release date's trailer description. You can check it out for yourself above.

Neva is the next game from the maker of the equally sad and beautiful Gris. We called Gris "an artful puzzle platformer that'll stay with you long after its short running time" in Eurogamer's review.

For more on Neva, we got a look at its gameplay back in June, as part of Summer Game Fest.

Elsewhere during today's Nintendo Direct, we also got word that Powerwash Simulator will be getting a Shrek DLC crossover and Sabotage Studio revealed its free DLC heading to Sea of Stars next year.
